labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: IANA registration issue
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Italo said:
"
-	The draft defines two YANG models (ietf-incident-types and ietf-incident) but in the IANA considerations only the registry for one model (ietf-indicent) is described: is it an omission there?
"

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Fixed, ietf-incident-types has been removed, IANA doesn't need to be updated now.

issues.title: reusability of ietf-incident-type
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Italo said:
"
-	Do we really need the split of the ietf-incident-types? Do you foreseen other modules which can re-use these definitions?
"

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Fixed, the solution is merge the type defined in ietf-incident-type into ietf-incident yang module.

issues.title: enumeration on leaf type
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Joe made the following comment:
"
 I see what I feel is a mix of terminology.  You have an enumeration on leaf type where “fault” reads as the type of incident being a fault.  To me, this is the type of problem (i.e., the cause of the incident).  The incident type might be an SLA violation.
"

issues.title: Relating to existing solutions
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Nigel said:
"
https://github.com/lllyfeng/incident-management/blob/f641fd7da4064bf05bbe4d8d5fab29229bb3d5e3/draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management-01.txt#LL152C42-L153C56

I suggest you change the text from "Theoretically, it is possible to compress a series of alarms into fewer incidents. " to "It is possible to compress a series of alarms into fewer incidents and there are many solutions in the market today that essentially do this to some degree. "
"

issues.title: Scope of the work
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Nigel said:
"
[incident-management/draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management-01.txt](https://github.com/lllyfeng/incident-management/blob/f641fd7da4064bf05bbe4d8d5fab29229bb3d5e3/draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management-01.txt#L23)

Line 23 in [f641fd7](https://github.com/lllyfeng/incident-management/commit/f641fd7da4064bf05bbe4d8d5fab29229bb3d5e3)

 system and related function interface requirements. 
I suggest that we take care not to define the internal process of identification of the incident but instead focus on the boundaries (alarms etc. in, incident reports out, client interaction with incident solution (inc. lifecycle)).

I think this intent needs to be clearly stated.
"

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Agree to have a clear scope, focus on YANG model external interface. the abstract and introduction are update to reflect this.
https://github.com/billwuqin/network-incident/commit/897ddc1fa9893ad1d31a433ce6d00f5f62268171

issues.title: align the ietf-incident-semantic-metadata.yang with draft-feng-opsawg-incident-management
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body: It was suggested by Roland Scott in adoption call in opsawg

issues.title: Terminology consistency issue
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
Nigel said:
As noted in the email chain below, there is a terminology challenge. We have taken an action to clean up the terminology usage and will aim to, where possible, align with terms used in the industry (although, as is often the case, the terms are used ambiguously and will need local definitions).

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
At the current stage, we use the term defined in TMF724A, which is network incident, in TMF724, incident defintion come from ITIL, which has been clarified in TMF724.
What we need here is TMF delegate review the term latest version to make sure we are consistent, there is no overstepping.

issues.title: Question from Lizhenqiang
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body: Please consider the following question: As the definition in this draft, network incident is defined from the perspective of a service and is raised by an incident server. Can the incident server know the real effect on the relevant services? For example, in figure 5 in this draft, VPN A may not perceive the link down between P1 and P2 because its packets are not lost during the interruption.
